action.content:
You are playing a text adventure game. I will describe what you can perceive in the game. You write the single action you want to take in the game starting with >. Only reply with an action.
For example:
> open cupboard

You can have up to two objects in your inventory at the same time.

Your goal for this game is to brew a potion following the potion recipe.

Once you have achieved your goal, write "> done" to end the game.

You are in a bedroom now. There are a book, a potion recipe, a wardrobe, a bed and a pillow. The book is on the bed. The potion recipe is on the bed. The wardrobe is closed. The pillow is on the floor. There is a passage to a reading room here.
action.label: context

action.content: I don't know what 'book and potion recipe' means.
action.label: context

action.content: I don't know what 'book and potion recipe' means.
action.label: context

action.content: > take book and potion recipe separately
action.label: response

action.content: I don't know what you mean.
action.label: context

action.content: You take the book. In your inventory you have a book.
action.label: context

action.content: You can't see any text on the book.
action.label: context

action.content: The wardrobe is now open. The wardrobe is empty.
action.label: context

action.content: This is a wardrobe. The wardrobe is openable and currently open. The wardrobe is open. The wardrobe is empty.
action.label: context

action.content: This is a pillow. The pillow is on the floor. The pillow is on. The pillow is takeable.
action.label: context

action.content: You take the pillow. In your inventory you have a book and a pillow.
action.label: context

action.content: You are in a reading room now. There are a table, a chair, a shelf, a side table and a couch. There are passages to a conservatory and a garden here.
action.label: context

action.content: This is a shelf. There is nothing on the shelf.
action.label: context

action.content: I don't know what 'around the reading room' means.
action.label: context
